paragraphs.name: 4b9f
paragraphs.text: The alpha-beta pruning does not influence the outcome of the minimax algorithm — it only makes it faster.
We’ll start by creating a function that just returns a random move from all of the possible moves:

paragraphs.name: 1cdb
paragraphs.text: A visualization of the minimax algorithm in an artificial position. The best move for white is b2-c3, because we can guarantee that we can get to a position where the evaluation is -50

59ddbd16d11f.title: I’ve been writing a Chess AI for one of my university classes and there are a few things that were…

paragraphs.text: I’ve been writing a Chess AI for one of my university classes and there are a few things that were glossed over or skipped. A-B Pruning and Minimax are not chess specific. I’d be curious the kind of optimizations that could be done because of the defined problem space.

f143d89b4f0e.title: Well, it influences the final outcome by pruning all solutions that involve a backward step along…

paragraphs.text: Well, it influences the final outcome by pruning all solutions that involve a backward step along the way…. No matter how good the end point is.

paragraphs.name: bb22

paragraphs.text: This code and game were built on the constants and a fixed set of perimeters. Exploring variables, overlaps in code may give new focus.
paragraphs.name: 4d3c

paragraphs.text: Awesome post. If you want to do a follow-up, along the lines of your suggested further improvements, you could implement negamax instead of minimax. You could also write about implementing transposition tables to make the algorithm faster. It’s a relatively easy add-on with a potentially big pay off in speed.

virtuals.subtitle: Building on that, you could also show us how to implement a simple Monte Carlo Tree Search. Would love to read about. Keep up the good work…

content.subtitle: Building on that, you could also show us how to implement a simple Monte Carlo Tree Search. Would love to read about. Keep up the good work…
